column4: i have a question about groups in ubuntu - why does the installer create a group of the same name as my user, and add me to that group?
doesn't it make more sense to simply add my user to the 'users' group, as would be the case on most other *nixes?
debian? really? i used to use debian and never noticed it do that
so every new user will get a group of the same name created too?
so, (sorry for a swathe of dumb questions), essentially each new user has no groups in common until the admin puts them in the 'users' group?
btw, i am running a fujitsu siemens amilo M 1425 notebook, and i was blown away by how everything "just works" with ubuntu
right down to 1280x800 on my widescreen LCD (ATI Mobility Radeon 9700)
can anybody offer a rough approximation of the amount of time it would take to do a debian install, and bring it up to the level of polishedness of ubuntu?
(being that i'm a die hard debian admin, and would still use it for console only servers, but i'm liking ubuntu more and more on my laptop)
i guess what i'm really asking is, is there any reason why in some situations debian might be better suited to a desktop?
it would take an hour, give or take. intall the woody base install, edit sources.list, upgrade to hoary ;)
no, i used debian sarge on about 30 servers in russia
i'm just trying to decide whether to stick with debian (at least on desktops) since it's what i know and use, or venture out into the unknown with ubuntu
(admittedly, installing ubuntu is a much nicer thought than installing fedora core)
the only thing that comes to mind for debian on the desktop is the long release cycle -> long support, stable boxen for years without bothering users with any changes in their lives
it is for me - i've only really discovered it!
apt is the most brilliant package system i've ever seen, so any distro that uses it wins my approval
